Read the whole post: "Monetary policy at the ZLB requires a perceived regime change to be effective, fiscal policy doesn’t — in fact, fiscal policy works better if people believe that it’s temporary, and will end when the economy recovers."

Fiscal policy works in a weak economy because it increases GDP beyond what private spending would otherwise result in. Government uses resources that would otherwise be idle. As GDP approaches its full potential, though, extra government spending competes with private spending for the same resources. In that case it can increase nominal GDP but not real GDP; i.e. cause inflation. That's why it's important that people know the spending is temporary.

I see the theoretical need for permanence on the monetary side (based on Krugman's Japan paper of 1999), but why the fiscal side as well?
If the government kicked in 2 or 3% of GDP via roads/bridges/research, etc, why would this need to be perceived as a permanent kick in order to be effective? It would employ people - i.e. put the money in the hands of people with a large marginal propensity to spend - and stimulate growth. Once that growth takes hold to the extent that the economy can absorb employment turnover, the government can back off. The program would need to be such that the government would commit to it as long as needed, but why forever? Why is the signal of "the fiscal stimulus will continue long enough" not good enough? Maybe I'm missing something on the difference between the theoretical notion of permanence and real permanence.

Seems to me that Buddhists aren't so much going against the grain as going with the Buddhist grain. There is s certain rough wisdom in Buddha's words, advanced for its time and in some cases still meaningful today; but isms are for idiots.

Buddhism was a term coined by early English translators of Dhamma texts, record of the Buddha's explanations about the laws of nature. No need to get hung up on an artificial linguistic device. To say all isms are for idiots is a good example of "self-righteousness".
No Buddhists shopping on Boxing Day? That's a disgrace! The Dharma is as present in the queue at the cash register as anywhere else . . .

Nowhere in the Buddha's teachings is such a thing as "invulnerability." The Buddha pointed out that all existence is based on the Law of Causality, one thing leads to another. There is no "First Cause" (thus no "Creator God").
Since all is driven by convergence and divergence of multitudes of conditions, everything can be characterized as "Dukkha" - a word that means all is subject to constant shifts and changes, impermanent, unstable, insecure, prone to breakdown (call it "vulnerable" if you like), and thus leading to disappointments, loss, grief, suffering.

Not understand this fact and the human tendency to desire, crave, grasp and cling cause endless bouts of grief, discontent. The Buddha pointed out to get out of this vortex one must live in such a way as "going against the current", to see the reality clearly without the bias of the deluded sense of "self" - the root of all human misery through "self-interests" & "Self-righteousness". While everyone is crazy with Black Friday and Boxing Day sales, or watch hours of violent football and ice hockey, Buddhists will turn their attention in the opposite direction, to calm, non-violence and serenity.

Going against the grain is never easy. It takes insight and fortitude. Buddhists understand very well that Buddhism is not for everyone. No point to knock on doors to preach the message. Professor May needs not worry about Buddhism, or try to explain it - until he gives it a try.

Some stuff in this puzzle I really liked, such as SLAKE and MALTHUS and MAPLE LEAF. That clue had me scratching my head plenty, until the crosses gave me MAPLE. Of course! MALTA came to me immediately, being the one euro entity most closely associated with a cross. Junk mover = SAIL was a nice giggle. I liked PINATAS and PITCHES both clued the same way, as something batted. And CROSSBOW as something that can be drawn in a forest. Very well done!

However, OIL COLOR is a pretty mushy answer for “common canvas coater”. “Verily” does not translate to TIS. Misdirect me, but don’t fib to me. Someone should be stood in the corner for VEHEMENCY. While I can see how such a word could be contrived, I’ll bet a thousand Maltese euros it hasn’t been used anywhere for the past hundred years, there being the much less clumsy VEHEMENCE available. Too many answers were very obscure. I don’t exactly live in today’s hyper-connected fast lane, but I doubt I’m not the only one who never heard of ADULTSWIM, ATARAXY, and SKYMALL. Worse, they were all mashed together, making for much dreary guessing on my part.
